text: The 9th World Championships in Athletics, under the auspices of the International Association of Athletics Federations, were held from 23 August to 31 August 2003 in the Stade de France in Saint-Denis, Seine-Saint-Denis, France. ==Men's results== ===Track=== 1999 | 2001 | 2003 | 2005 | 2007 {| |- |rowspan=2|100 m |Kim Collins ||10.07 |Darrel Brown ||10.08 |Darren Campbell || 10.08 (SB) |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|200 m |John Capel ||20.30 |Darvis Patton ||20.31 |Shingo Suetsugu ||20.38 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|400 m |Tyree Washington ||44.771 |Marc Raquil ||44.79 (NR) |Michael Blackwood ||44.80 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|800 m |Djabir Saïd-Guerni ||1:44.81 |Yuriy Borzakovskiy ||1:44.84 |Mbulaeni Mulaudzi ||1:44.90 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|1500 m |Hicham El Guerrouj ||3:31.77 |Mehdi Baala ||3:32.31 |Ivan Heshko ||3:33.17 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|5000 m |Eliud Kipchoge ||12:52.79 (CR) |Hicham El Guerrouj ||12:52.83 |Kenenisa Bekele ||12:53.12 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|10,000 m |Kenenisa Bekele ||26:49.57 (CR) |Haile Gebrselassie ||26:50.77 (SB) |Sileshi Sihine ||27:01.44 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|Marathon |Jaouad Gharib ||2:08:31 (CR) |Julio Rey ||2:08:38 |Stefano Baldini ||2:09:14 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|110 m hurdles |Allen Johnson ||13.12 |Terrence Trammell ||13.20 (SB) |Liu Xiang ||13.23 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|400 m hurdles |Félix Sánchez ||47.25 (WL) |Joey Woody ||48.18 (SB) |Periklís Iakovákis ||48.24 |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|3000 m steeplechase |Saif Saaeed Shaheen ||8:04.39 |Ezekiel Kemboi ||8:05.11 |Eliseo Martin ||8:09.09 (PB) |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|20 km race walk |Jefferson Pérez ||1:17:21 (WBP) |Paquillo Fernández ||1:18:00 (SB) |Roman Rasskazov ||1:18:07 (SB) |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|50 km race walk |Robert Korzeniowski ||3:36:03 (WBP) |German Skurygin ||3:36:42 (NR) |Andreas Erm ||3:37:46 (NR) |- |colspan=6| |- |rowspan=2|4 x 100 m relay | John Capel Bernard Williams Darvis Patton Joshua J. who ran in preliminary rounds. 1 Jerome Young of the United States originally finished first in 44.50, but was disqualified after he tested positive for drugs in 2004. 2 The United States (Calvin Harrison, Tyree Washington, Derrick Brew, Jerome Young) originally finished first in 2:58.88, but were disqualified after Jerome Young and Calvin Harrison both tested positive for drugs in 2004. |- |rowspan="2"|Heptathlon |||7001 (WL) |||6755 (SB) |||6524 (SB) |- |colspan=6|Swedish Carolina Klüft won with big margin following a breaking of her personal best in six of the seven events and the totals. She was the third woman ever to score more than 7000 points. |- |- bgcolor= e8e8e8 |colspan=7| |} ==Medal table== ==References== For more information about these results including in-depth results of all heats and finals that include photo finish, wind readings and reaction times see the link below. * IAAF Championship 2003 Category:World Athletics Championships World Championships in Athletics World Championships in Athletics Category:International athletics competitions hosted by France Category:International sports competitions hosted by Paris Category:Athletics in Paris Category:August 2003 sports events in Europe
title: 2003 World Championships in Athletics
